title: I am being sued by a creditor & have been served. What happens if I don't show up to court? Can they garnish my wages?
question: What if I don't have the money to pay them back?
answers: Yes. This is a serious matter. You must respond to these court documents timely so as not to be put in default on the debt. Please contact a local attorney ASAP so that your rights will be protected. Good Luck.

The first video on my website gives a quick overview of the options when sued on a credit card debt. Please see my blog postings, below, on your (1) next steps after being served with a summons and complaint for an unpaid debt and (2) risks associated with DIY representation of a debt collection lawsuit in Cal Superior Court.

As explained in my next steps blog, the deadline to file a response in court is not related to the filing date of the lawsuit, it is based on the date they served the defendant and the manner of service.

Yes, they can garnish your wages if they get a money judgment. I have a legal guide on Avvo, which I linked below, that explains that further.

I'd recommend you contact an attorney for direct and confidential help, so that you can explore your options fully. If you contact my office for a free consultation, please mention this posting on Avvo.

First, you need to file an Answer. You will have a court date only if you file an Answer with the court. If you cannot afford to pay the court filing fee, you can request a fee waiver.

After you file your answer, the debt collector will need to prove its case in court with admissible evidence. You can negotiate. Or make them show up in court.

If they get a judgment, and if they know where you work, they can garnish 25% of your wages. They can put a lien on any real estate that you own. They can levy upon any stocks and bonds that you have. If all you own are necessities of life, they can take nothing.

If you don't file an Answer or if you file an Answer and don't appear for trial, the Court can issue a Default Judgment against you. The creditor can lien your real property, levy your bank accounts or garnish your wages. If possible, call the creditor's attorney to determine whether you can work out a settlement or a payment arrangement. If you have other debts, you may want to consider discharging them in bankruptcy. Good luck.

If you don't file an answer and show-up to court, you can have default, followed by a default judgment, entered against you. Then, once they have a judgment, they can, likely, garnish your wages. Even if you don't have the money to pay them back, you can try to settle with them and/or work-out a payment plan.
